captions.text:
We’ve never seen them directly, yet we know
they are there, lurking within dense star

clusters or wandering the dust lanes of the
galaxy, where they prey on stars or swallow
planets whole.

Our Milky Way may harbor millions of black
holes, the ultra dense remnants of dead stars.

But now, in the universe far beyond our galaxy,
there's evidence of something far more ominous,

a breed of black holes that has reached incomprehensible
size and destructive power.

Just how large, and violent, and strange can
they get?

A new era in astronomy has revealed a universe
long hidden to us.

High-tech instruments sent into space have
been tuned to sense high-energy forms of light

– x-rays and gamma rays – that are invisible
to our eyes and do not penetrate our atmosphere.

On the ground, precision telescopes are equipped
with technologies that allow them to cancel
out the blurring effects of the atmosphere.

They are peering into the far reaches of the
universe, and into distant caldrons of light
and energy.

In some distant galaxies, astronomers are
now finding evidence that space and time are

being shattered by eruptions so vast they
boggle the mind.

We are just beginning to understand the impact
these outbursts have had on the universe:

on the shapes of galaxies, the spread of elements
that make up stars and planets, and ultimately
the very existence of Earth.

The discovery of what causes these eruptions
has led to a new understanding of cosmic history.

Back in 1995, the Hubble space telescope was
enlisted to begin filling in the details of
that history.

Astronomers selected tiny regions in the sky,
between the stars. For days at a time, they

focused Hubble’s gaze on remote regions
of the universe.

These Hubble Deep Field images offered incredibly
clear views of the cosmos in its infancy.

What drew astronomers’ attention were the
tiniest galaxies, covering only a few pixels
on Hubble’s detector.

Most of them do not have the grand spiral
or elliptical shapes of large galaxies we

see close to us today. Instead, they are irregular,
scrappy collections of stars.

The Hubble Deep Field confirmed a long-standing
idea that the universe must have evolved in

a series of building blocks, with small galaxies
gradually merging and assembling into larger
ones.

You can see evidence of this pattern by looking
out into the universe. Many galaxies are gyrating

around one another. Some are crashing together,
others ripping each other apart.

Gravity calls the tune as these galaxies draw
together, exchanging stars and gas, and, over
time, merging to form larger composite galaxies.

This came to be known as the hierarchical
picture of cosmic history, in which the universe

evolved from the ground up, with its structures
growing larger and larger over time.

A team operating at the Subaru Observatory
atop Hawaii’s Mauna Kea volcano examined

one of the deepest galaxies known, whose light
has taken nearly 13 billion years to reach
us.

It was a messenger from a time not long after
the universe was born.

This object is known as a quasar, short for
“quasi-stellar radio source.” It offered

a stunning surprise. A small region in its
center is so bright that astronomers believe

its light is coming not from a collection
of stars, but from a single object of at least
a billion times the mass of our sun.

This beacon is generated by gas falling onto
the object and heating up to extreme temperatures.

The only thing known to generate this much
power is a swirling caldron, where space suddenly

turns dark as it merges into a giant black
hole.

For astronomers, the question was: how did
this black hole get so big so early in the
history of the universe?

It likely got its start in an early generation
of stars, often known as population 3 stars.

Made up of hydrogen, they are thought to have
been hundreds of times the mass of the sun.

These giant stars burned hot and fast, and
died young.

A star is like a cosmic pressure-cooker. In
its core, the crush of gravity produces such

intense heat that atoms are stripped and rearranged.
Lighter elements like hydrogen and helium

fuse together to form heavier ones like calcium,
oxygen, silicon, and finally iron.

When enough iron accumulates in the core of
the star, it begins to collapse of its own
weight.

That can send a shock wave racing outward
that literally blows the star apart in a supernova.

At the moment the star dies, if enough matter
falls into its core, it can collapse to a
point, forming a black hole.

The first generations of stars and black holes
burst onto the cosmic scene in a time of incredible
turbulence.

Within primordial gas clouds, stars were being
born in dense knots. They gave rise to black

holes that began to swallow more and more
matter.

A computer simulation of the early universe
shows just how quickly these voracious monsters
were able to grow.

The project, by scientists at Carnegie Mellon
University, was designed to recreate a region

in the early universe that measured over a
hundred million light years on a side.

It shows what took place in the first one
billion years of cosmic history.

This virtual universe is set in motion by
equations describing the properties of gas,

the energy released in star birth and the
outward motion of time and space.

The result: an intricate cosmic web, with
gravity drawing matter into filaments and

knots like a vast tangle of interconnected
spiders’ webs.

Inside the densest regions is where the largest
galaxies, and black holes, grew. Here, circles

indicate the appearance of black holes deep
in the data.

As they gain weight, by eating up their surroundings,
the circles grow larger. A few, in the largest

galaxies, reach ultra massive proportions,
billions of times the mass of the sun.

These black holes were not just swallowing
gas.

The orbiting Chandra X-Ray Observatory was
dispatched to look into distant galaxies for
black holes on growth spurts.

Scientists looked for pockets of gas and stars
glowing hotly in X-ray light.

What Chandra found was that the core of some
distant galaxies countained hot pairs, twin

supermassive black holes drawn together by
gravity.

Black holes by nature resist this dark marriage.
As the two approach each other, they go into
an orbit that could last virtually forever.

To learn what allows them to merge, we go
back to the ideas developed by Albert Einstein.

He said that when massive bodies accelerate
or whip around each other, they literally

disturb the fabric of space, causing it to
ripple like a disturbance on a pond.

When these ripples move outward, they carry
with them the energy of the pair’s orbit,
causing them to spiral closer.

When this dance of death comes to an end,
that’s when the pair joins together to form
a larger black hole.

That moment may be approaching for a quasar
called OJ-287, at 3.5 billion light years
away.

Flareups in the surrounding region have led
astrophysicists to conclude that another black
hole is flying around it.

By measuring the giant's gravitational hold
on its companion, astronomers estimate its
mass at 18 billion solar masses.

For a time, OJ-287 was the largest black hole
ever detected. It no longer is.

Deep in the heart of the Coma galaxy cluster,
a mere 321 million light years away, lies
a giant eliptical galaxy known as NGC 4889.

Astronomers used several large telescopes
to measure the speed at which stars are orbiting

around the center. They used that data to
calculate the mass of the central object,

a whopping 21 billion solar masses, give or
take a few billion.

Theoretically there are no limits to how much
weight a black hole can gain.

And yet even the largest black holes, and
their host galaxies, seem to obey limits.

What holds them back has to do with the way
clusters of galaxies evolve, a pattern long
noted by scientists.

This computer simulation shows the evolution
of a galaxy cluster in the early universe.

The gravity of the entire region draws small
galaxies by the thousands, along with great
streams of gas, into the center.

So why doesn’t the central galaxy, and the
black hole that resides within it, capture

all this matter? Why don’t they swallow
the entire cluster?

You can see the answer in a region called
MS0735. At two and a half billion light years

away, it appears in visible light to be a
typical galaxy cluster.

In X-ray light, you can see that it’s enveloped
in a cloud of hot gas, measured at nearly
50 million degrees.

Hollowed out of this cloud are two immense
cavities up to 600,000 light years across.

That’s enough room in each to stuff 600
galaxies the size of our Milky Way.

Now add in a radio image of the cluster. You
can see two vast streams of matter pushing
out from the center.

That’s a give-away that the cavities were
formed by an eruption in the core of the giant

central galaxy. Two jets, shooting out of
a central black hole, have launched blast

waves that plowed through the gas that makes
up the inter-galactic medium.

The 
energy it took to carve out these Xray cavities
is remarkable, the equivalent of several billion
supernovae, according to one calculation.

In fact, this has been referred to as the
largest single eruption recorded since the
big bang.

It was generated by a black hole that weighs
in at around 10 billion solar masses.

Black hole jets like this have been seen all
around the universe, including in our own
cosmic neighborhood.

This is the famous M87 galaxy, at the center
of the Virgo galaxy cluster, around 50 million
light years away

Astronomers have been intensively studying
the black hole that lurks in its heart, and

recently estimated its mass at 6.6 billion
solar masses.

It powers a pair of high-powered jets that
are plowing through the galaxy.

But how does a black hole, a creature famous
for hiding in the dark, emit this much energy?

Think of a black hole as the eye of a cosmic
hurricane, kept rotating by all the stars,

gas, and other black holes that fall into
it.

As this matter flows in, it forms a spinning
donut-like feature called an accretion disk,
which works like a dynamo.

The spinning motion of the disk generates
magnetic fields that twist around and channel

some of the inflowing matter out into a pair
of high-energy beams, or jets.

How much energy depends on the black hole’s
gravity, and how much matter has already crashed
through the event horizon.

Is this just another frightening spectacle
of Nature? Or is it part of a more profound

process at work? It shows that a monster black
hole will not be forcefed.

The largest black holes in the universe probably
rose between 10 and 12 billion years ago,

the age of the quasars. By releasing energy
in the form of jets, they heated up their

surrounding regions. This prevented gas from
collapsing into the central galaxy, and allowed

smaller galaxies on the periphery to form
and grow.

But the impact the black holes did not stop
there. This Chandra image of the Hydra A galaxy

cluster shows the same immense hot cavities,
glowing in X-ray light, as well as a jet blasting
out of its central galaxy.

Gas along the edge of the jet was found to
contain high levels of iron and other metals

probably generated by supernova explosions
in the center.

By pushing these metals into regions beyond,
a black hole seeded more distant galaxies

with the elements needed to form stars and
solar systems like ours.

The black holes in these more remote galaxies
then seeded their own environments. This is

what might be happening in Centaurus A, also
known as the “hamburger galaxy.”

Peering through the dense dust lanes that
dominate our line of sight, astronomers have

come to believe that it’s actually two galaxies
in the act of colliding.

In X-rays, you can see a jet erupting from
the center.

This computer simulation shows the effect
of such a merger on black holes. As the two

galaxies pass by each other, the pull of gravity
disrupts their spiral shapes, forcing huge
volumes of gas into their cores.

As the black holes begin to feed, they emit
blast waves that push much of the loose gas
out beyond the boundaries of the new galaxy.

In the final steps of this cosmic dance, the
two black holes merge, and emit one final
blast.

To think that our Earth, our solar system,
ourselves are the beneficiaries of these far-away

monsters. The largest black holes have played
dual roles in a great cosmic struggle. They

are the product of gravity’s relentless
inward pull, the force that has drawn matter

into galaxies, clusters, and the structures
they form.

But with their incredible power, they emit
energy that pushes back on gravity. In so

doing, these strange and powerful objects
have become the master architects of space
and time.

comments.text:
In the center of the universe there is a black hole. That means we were all 
supposedly born in this black hole. Inside this black hole there is other 
black holes, or inside the universe, I should say. This means that if we 
try to escape our universe, which is a black hole, it'll be nearly 
impossible before we die as a form of atoms. However, we would manage to 
see a glimpse of what is outside of our galaxy. Could it be a new galaxy, a 
big black or white pile of nothingness, or maybe we could be tiny midgets 
that a giant is playing with in this toy ball. So... the only way to 
"escape" our universe is to go inside the black holes within our own. But 
then... we haven't escaped. We're trapped inside something inside the black 
hole inside the universe inside the galaxy. So.. could it be that we visit 
a glimpse of a new galaxy for a small period of time before we thin out to 
atoms, and could we see civilization? My guess is, black holes otherwise 
known as big piles of mass, so powerful, could stretch us between 
dimensions, serving as a portal to a new world.

If you were to orbit a black hole at just the right speed to not get pulled 
inward, you experience half the time of everyone else. This means, if you 
were to be on that orbit 5 years, then somehow get back to Earth, everyone 
would have aged 10 years. You'd have only aged 5 years. You'd had visit a 
future Earth, and "technically" be younger than everyone else. You would 
have traveled through time. Therefore... black holes are time machines. Not 
practically, though﻿

comments.text:
You're insulting devout Christians who study inflationary cosmology, 
quantum mechanics, Big Bang nucleosynthesis, etc. Just wanted you to know 
that.

What makes you believe a deity didn't create the universe we're studying? 
Why do you think the universe isn't real? Black holes are real (The 
cosmological anomaly called a gravitational singularity that we currently 
only half understand). Space is real. All of it is real, given the standard 
perspective. This video doesn't refute theism. The fact that you're 
considering this video a refutation of theism tells me just how 
close-minded you are. Science isn't fake. Religious people recognize that. 
Creationists, who are centrally concentrated in the US, do not. Even 
Christian leaders advocate much of the Old Testament is allegorical and not 
to be taken literally. You cannot explain away science.

If you read this, you're using your angular gyrus, frontal lobe and 
temporal lobe of your brain, as well as grey matter, while the retina in 
each eye processes the photons reflected off your screen as information 
translated into a picture through activation of frequency-specific optic 
neurons that transmit information through your optic nerve to said areas of 
your brain. Just as I can tell you that, I can tell you science is real.

I can take my telescope and look at Saturn and Jupiter and tell you my 
telescope, with a 6 inch primary mirror which has a resolution of 1.5 
arcseconds, cannot see Jupiter or Saturn with good resolution. To see the 
bands of Jupiter, you would need a telescope with a resolution of about 1 
arcsecond. Because I can tell you that, I can tell you science very much is 
real.

If the speck before the big bang was so tiny that it created the universe,

what would happen. A black hole isn't matter or energy. So since that speck

draw the black hole near, correct? But it couldn't "suck it in" because it

comments.author: Kraig Atkinson

comments.text:
A black hole is a mathematically defined region of spacetime exhibiting 
such a strong gravitational pull that no particle or electromagnetic 
radiation can escape from it.[1] The theory of general relativity predicts 
that a sufficiently compact mass can deform spacetime to form a black 
hole.[2] The boundary of the region from which no escape is possible is 
called the event horizon. Although crossing the event horizon has enormous 
effect on the fate of the object crossing it, it appears to have no locally 
detectable features. In many ways a black hole acts like an ideal black 
body, as it reflects no light.[3][4] Moreover, quantum field theory in 
curved spacetime predicts that event horizons emit Hawking radiation, with 
the same spectrum as a black body of a temperature inversely proportional 
to its mass. This temperature is on the order of billionths of a kelvin for 
black holes of stellar mass, making it essentially impossible to observe.
﻿

comments.text:
ECO's are a much more sensible explanation.  Same basic thing without the 
2 impossibilitys under GR of the Event Horizion and Center Singularity .... 
They have Apparant Horizions and the center can not become a singularity 
because it would take infinite time to create in GR.  Hence the Eternally 
Collapsing Object explanation where the center never actually forms and the 
Horizion is apparent rather than absolute.  The Eddington limit also keeps 
the Singularity from being able to form .... The outward pressure of heat 
is an opposing force to gravity so it reaches equilibrium before the 
Singularity could form.  Added mass goes towards the center but never 
actually makes a center Singularity,  and as it grows takes longer than 
longer for more mass to get towards the center for both reasons. 

 The idea the center would be some tiny point or ring of zero volume is 
absurd , at the least it would be an area where time became so slow that it 
would be a cloud of very slowly moving energy (slowly to the center) moving 
slower and slower as it went to the center , slowing everything else behind 
it down as it went and being slowed by the Eddington effect never reaching 
zero.  The truth is the Black Hole model is really just very poor Math.

The Event Horizion Telescope should provide some observational evidence as 
to which Model is more correct in a few years or less. ﻿

comments.text:
There's nothing special about black holes... Time slows down to a halt for 
the matter as it approaches and reaches the speed of light.  So we can have 
literally the whole universe traveling at the speed of light, toward a 
small area, and it wouldn't touch/explode/react with surrounding matter 
because time has either stopped or is moving at an extremely slow pace.  
One day in the VERY DISTANT future the matter in each black hole will 
finally begin to reach that milli second where it begins to react with 
surrounding matter causing a massive explosion.  Keep in mind that the 
universe is ever expanding, so all other black holes will be so far away 
that they might as well be out of the picture.  Could black holes actually 
be Big Bangs in the making?﻿

Today's computers are becoming more and more complex. The core of these 
machines is electrical energy, and the binary code. The system we are part

cannot see. These particles are much like the pixels that make up your

comments.text:
It is most likely that all matter has come from, and is still coming from, 
the central point in every galaxy that is called the 'black hole'. These 
central points not only spew out matter, they also repel all matter, thus 
the expansion of the universe. The spewed out matter from these center 
points builds stars, billions of stars, which have their own gravity.  The 
matter spewed out by these center points is only what they call 'black 
matter'.

The mutual gravity of the stars hold hold the galexies in a loose 
organization and imprison the central point (if it moves in one direction, 
that side will back off but the mutual gravity will pull the other side in, 
leaving everthing much as it was). Spinning central points produce spiral 
galaxies and the others produce globular galaxies.

Galaxies never collide. Neighboring 'central points' give that impression, 
but they are just scrambling to get out of each other's way.

Many questions to ask. I think this would put an age on the universe but 
are these central points still popping up? I have no idea where they come 
from. Do they stretch on to infinity?

But, all in all, it's a better theory that 'the Big Bang'. Who really 
believed in that exploding walnut?﻿

comments.text:
+SpaceRip  You failed to tell us the SIZE of that 18 billion solar mass 
Black Hole. :)

So let me work this out: The sun would be around 3 miles across if shrunk 
to a BH maybe a little more so lets say 5 kilometres. 5 * 18,000,000,000 
= 90 billion K across.
The speed of light in a vacuum is:  299,792,458 meters per second, so the 
formula is:
(1000*90000000000)/(299792458*3600*24) = light days across .... :)

Hold on where's the calculator...thats roughly 3.47 light days.  Or 
55,924,936,308 miles across.
Yes, the most amazing fact about Black Holes was left out again. The size 
of BH's is simple to calculate when adding them to each other, as their 
radius or diameter is proportional. So all I need to do to figure out the 
size of any 2 colliding BH's is to just add the diameter of each to get the 
combined size. AND that is the fucking most incredible piece of info I've 
ever come across in astrophysics.  Just calculate what that does to the 
density, it goes down 4 fold.
Proof: 2*2*2 = 8, add that to itself, 4*4*4 = 64: One would be expecting 16 
cubic something but we get 64, a 4 fold decrease in density in something 
that has no substances- lol.
The next calculation is to find the size of the BH that represents the 
average density of the Universe... its been done and it is pretty much the 
same.

The biggest Black Hole is the one we are living in!﻿

comments.author: Mitrh

comments.text:
+Chad Gant You keep bringing up that science changes and referring to it as 
a belief. This is so naive of you it's painful. So let me break it down for 
you. Science has not changed. Science is a process by which you form a 
hypothesis and then gather data to prove or disprove your hypothesis. In 
which case, if successfully proven, your hypothesis becomes proven fact. 
And you bring up such childish examples such as the debate over Pluto. 
There is a whole slew of reasons why it should or should not be labeled a 
planet and it has nothing to do with actual science and everything to do 
with preference for having a word describe things relatively neatly. Simply 
put 'Pluto aint big enough to be no damn planet.' 

Now. You also keep saying you aren't here to start trouble and everyone is 
free to believe what they want, but then you keep throwing logical fallacy 
in a manner of insult at Science itself. 

Even stating something so false as to say that we have not observed or 
proven any evolution in man or other creatures, which is FALSE. Because we 
have. Most of it is behavioral in animals and-... You know what. You like 
reading a book so much, research it yourself so YOU can turn around and 
claim its all made up.

"His word has never changed." "The Bible has never changed." Actually.. it 
has.. more times than there are languages in the world. If I go to the 
church down the street, I'm going to get a different interpretation of the 
Letters to Corinth than I would get from the church downtown even though 
both are labeled as Baptist. You say his word hasn't changed and yet you 
have HOW many different denominations and all coming from the same book? 
From the old testament alone you have multiple faiths and interpretations, 
each fighting over one another because you have Judaism and Hasidic 
Judaism, and several other forms of a Judaism. But at least they only have 
pretty much two main groups. Christianity however haves HUNDREDS. Even 
breaking it down to the basic fundamentally different groups you still have 
7 different main denominations of Christianity. Hey! That's God's perfect 
number isn't it? Oh wait that's according to the numerology freaks that 
love finding significance in numbers within the bible and think themselves 
scholars and mathematicians for doing so. Seriously though! Catholicism, 
Protestantism, Eastern orthodoxy, Oriental Orthodoxy, Anglicanism, 
Restorationism and non-trinitarianism (technically this makes eight but 
they're similar enough), and Church of the east. I'm also going to guess 
that without reading about each and every single one of these you will have 
NO IDEA which one of these denominations your church falls under beyond 
"Not catholicism." It is very VERY rare I find a 'Christian' that really 
even KNOWS the book they claim to love so much. so let me ask you thius, 
can you really say that his word hasn't changed? If it hasn't been changed 
and all of the priests, scholars, etc are in perfect agreement with each 
other about the meaning behind the words in the bible, then how do you have 
so many denominations and disagreements about the meaning of ONE BOOK?! 

Your religion sways whichever way the wind blows around the man with the 
most religious power and influence and politicians for centuries have used 
Religion, twisting its vague words as the means to their ends ever since 
and still do. Science changes according to discovery and advancement in 
technology and each new discovery and experimentation brings us further and 
further into our information and technological age. Which brings me to the 
fact you claim to believe in God over science and yet you have science to 
thank for that plastic thing your fingers keep bumping into to not make any 
trouble on the youtubes and keep everyone lovin' jeebus. 

And for those of you who keep pointing out that Science cannot disprove 
God, you're right, the concept of an omniscient being capable of 
controlling, changing and deciding everything if he so chooses cannot be 
disproven. The very concept gives the believer a way out of any fact, 
experiment or discovery and they can literally shoot down any argument they 
present to them with "Because God." It is the perfect unbeatable concept. I 
can say "Well we've proven the big bang theory," and a Christian can say 
"Well God DID say let there be light and...so there was!" Or I can say 
"Well we've finally scoped and collected all the data ever on the entire 
universe and know everything about all the galaxies ever" and they can say 
"Awesome. God's clearly in Heaven which is not a part of this universe 
because that's how he designed it." So yeah... by the very design of the 
CONCEPT, God cannot be disproven. So stop feeling so proud when you say it 
like it means something, it really means nothing more than the fact that 
there's an entire book explaining a concept that has every way out of an 
argument ever in the simplest way possible as if it were created by a 
five-year-old who was describing their newly made-up superhero. But I 
digress. 

And this isn't to say I believe or don't believe in God or A God, I just 
think how people present their supposed faith is moronic, illogical and 
conceptually misleading to the general public and that religion and morals 
hinder the progress of our race.

Quite frankly I would love to meet a Christian one day, but I am now 
certain it would require a little blue box and a custom-made screwdriver 
because my hypothesis is that a real christian has not walked this earth 
for at least fifteen hundred years or so. Who wants to go digging?

Want me to prove I can think more than you?

All science is a collection of statements about the physical world obtained

acquired from imperfect senses which that someone else thought was what he 
KNEW, when in fact it was only what he THOUGHT he knew. 
Science may be provable but no single experiment proves anything right, and 
no collection of arguments makes something true. All scientific data is to 
be revised at all times because our knowledge is not perfect. 

We have only 5 senses according to physical science; the others can only be 
felt, but are denied simply because we cannot prove them with scientific 
theory.

Quantum mechanics is currently delving into spirituality and esoteric 
sciences unconsciously, simply because of the fact that they're denying 
that observation creates reality based on relative perception; which 
completely explains why things can exist and not exist at the same time.

Existence itself is also an incomplete concept for many people. Plato

Quick question. What would happen if we took a star about 1000 times the

hole is large enough it can't gulp a star in one go. We've never seen a 
star and black hole hit one another either. Any thoughts?﻿
comments.author: pyro111100

comments.text:
It would compress the star before it even got close to the black hole. I 
think you're underestimating the strength of gravity around a black hole.

Take a black hole size of a tea spoon, it'll create an event horizon a few 
kilometers in diameter, if I remember correctly. And even if you're far 
outside the event horizon, the gravity will be so strong that it'll rip 
your body apart just by being near it.

But as for your example: A big star runs into a small black hole. The 
center of the star will compress and disappear into the black hole. Now 
that there's nothing holding the star up, the outer part of the star will 
collapse in on itself. So yeah, the entire star will be eaten by the black 
hole, even if the star is a billion times larger.

comments.text:
Just like the moon can't suddenly crash into earth, something orbiting a 
black hole shouldn't be able to suddenly crash into the black hole. For 
that, it needs to loose it's orbital velocity, so something must slow it 
down.
I don't *think* that is something that happens.

Earth started out as a few rocks, but eventually got hit by so many other 
rocks that it grew really big, until the solar system calmed down and 
became less chaotic with less free rocks flying around. Nowadays we rarely 
get hit by asteroids, and earth isn't really growing anymore.
In the same way, black holes start as a giant star collapses, and then 
sucks a lot of stuff in until the only stuff that's left are the things 
that are in stable orbit around it, and then it won't grow any more.

I'm just speculating, I haven't studied this specific question. Perhaps 
there's some factor I'm leaving out.

The satirical weekly evil TERRORIST paper has on numerous occasions 
published cartoons insulting Islam and Muslims, tagging them as “freedom of 
speech.” However, the magazine has itself in the past failed to abide by 
this stance.

In 2009, the satirical weekly dismissed Maurice Sinet, a political 
cartoonist with Charlie Hebdo for 20 years, for his cartoons that allegedly 
ridiculed the relationship of former French President Nicolas Sarkozy’s son 
with a wealthy Jewish woman.

In the column, the 80-year-old cartoonist commented on rumors that 
Sarkozy’s son, Jean, intended to convert from Catholicism to Judaism to 
marry the Jewish woman for financial reasons, saying, “He’ll go a long way 
in life, that little lad.”

At the time, Charlie Hebdo’s editor, Philippe Val, found the piece 
offensive and asked Sinet to apologize, but the cartoonist strictly refused 
to do so.

Sinet then faced charges of “anti-Semitism” and “inciting racial hatred. He 
was fired and taken to court by the so-called International League against 
Racism and Anti-Semitism﻿

comments.author: Rooster

comments.text:
You've got it wrong. It's not just speed that causes time dilation, but 
anything with mass curves space to make other masses come towards it. In 
other words, this "curving" of spacetime is literally gravity. A black hole 
forms simply because there is too much stuff in a given region of space. 
For instance, if you could compress the Earth down to the size of a peanut, 
it would collapse into a black hole, since the given mass is in an area 
hat's smaller than said the mass's Schwarzschild radius (any mass that's 
smaller than its Schwarzschild radius becomes a black hole). I hope that 
helps :).

began by itself from that single point.

FYI, this is the level that the average man pushes the subject from. If you 
learned something more, than I can guarantee it isn't what is on the 
frontline of the debate because the frontline is populated, traditionally, 
by the average man and the version I've heard is guaranteed to be the party

way of a politician is to 'understand the irascibility of the mindless

this nation's increasingly liberal foolishness AND the layman's version of

I have provided evidence of God's existence but maybe you can't see it for 
what it is, so I'll break it down: There are ONLY two prevailing arguments 
regarding cosmic origin. There is the belief that everything was made by 
God, or a god depending on your belief system. And there is the belief that 
there is no such thing as gods of any kind and that everything came about 
on its own. Atheists don't believe in the existence of God in any form so 
you're pushing the belief that the universe came about on its own by 
default. If that isn't what you're saying then what the hell are you saying?

Logically, there are only two sides in this debate: Origin by divine 
creation or by evolution. There is no third option, unless you want to 
argue that the universe only exists because we are here perceiving it to 
exist which is just ridiculous. As such, to disprove one is to support the 
other.

All my evidence comes STRAIGHT from what I was taught in school or what 
so-called "Experts" have stated. The rest is logical inference based on 
what I took in and considered. Besides, information is free to absorb and 
expand on as it seems necessary. There is no point in paying $50K to go to 
college just to learn what some professor has learned from their professor 
who learned it from their professor who learned it from their professor all 
the way back to when such an idea I would be learning about was originally 
thought up and verified, all the while without being expanded upon in any 
grand detail. Why should I pay $50K just to learn what amounts to written 
hearsay and earn a professionally bedazzled piece of paper that tells all 
who see it that I know enough to parrot what I was taught?

You say "Expert" and that is what the word means to me given modern social 
foolishness and assumations: A person who is validated by a stupid piece of 
paper that certifies that they know what those that taught them know. If 
they were taught by someone who knows little to nothing correct on a 
subject and they pass, they are an expert but they still know next to 
nothing on the subject.

Keep your Bachelors of Science degree. It means nothing more than "you know 
what they knew" and it carries more weight professionally being a 
Bachelor's degree but that doesn't mean that you're any more knowledgeable 
than they were or that they knew what they were talking about, only that 
they knew what those before them talked about. It also means that you paid 
money for what you know which, sadly, is more important than being 
knowledgeable these days. *That's what a degree means to me.*

comments.text:
+Monochromicornicopia Response is lengthy, but a lot is spacing to aid in 
following so bare with me because it isn't fair to just expect you to put 
the pieces together without explanation.

"You seem to think it is the atheists responsibility to disprove god. It 
isn't."

And this argument again. You aren't the first to say that but at least you 
aren't outright claiming that Evolution is correct by default and that it 
is the theist's job to disprove it. That is an improvement at least.

I have tried to give ample evidence to the existence of God and most 
atheists simply refuse to accept it and say that it doesn't make sense. 
But, in the hopes that you will consider it, I'll restate:

1) I've already pointed out the basic error in mathematics as opposed to 
what Evolution insists is true and why the numbers don't add up as it were.

2) *Conservation of Matter* states that matter can't be created or 
destroyed, only transformed. No matter how you spin it, the Big Bang Theory 
(BBT) insists that matter and energy came from nothing. Either dimensional 
planes touched and generated the energy necessary for it (pretty 
far-fetched considering the massive transfer of energy that would have 
required and the sheer coincidence of everything turning out THIS way) or 
all the matter in the universe was compacted into a singularity sized space 
(in which case the matter still wasn't really created but left over from a 
previous form and had to come from somewhere else).

The first one notes a problem that was demonstrated in a graphic depicting 
an open dryer with all the clothes inside neatly folded and stacked. It 
stated: According to the law of averages, that should happen at least once. 
Ever since the first dryer was made and put to use and after millions upon 
millions of drying cycles, have you ever heard of that happening naturally 
or even coming closer than one jumbled mess?

The second one denotes a problem based on the rules of Time which states 
that EVERYTHING bound by it needs to have its beginning and come from 
somewhere. The BBT insists that there was nothing before the event 
mentioned. One atheist stated that the plane before the universe's 
existence may have been capable of producing such an outcome but that is 
just conjecture and can't be proven.
     *P.S.* I have been stuck on the notion of how God can exist without a 
beginning as we know it. I have come to accept that, as the creator of 
Time, he isn't bound by it. Imagine if a clock became sentient and how we 
would look to it given the rules on which its operation is bound: It would 
see us and insist we are broken or illusions because it couldn't comprehend 
our existence.

3) *This is thanks to Neil deGrasse Tyson regarding his statement on the 
truth behind E=MC^2.* The equation's principle states that matter and 
energy are interchangeable. If you turn energy into matter, you get matter 
AND anti-matter. You will not get one without the other as however many 
experiments have shown. However, for every particle of matter in the 
universe, there is an instance where matter was made *WITHOUT* anti-matter 
because it still exists today. According to Neil deGrasse Tyson, the 
universe would have cooled billions of years ago and all matter would have 
cancelled with anti-matter leaving nothing but energy in the universe if 
E=MC^2 was absolute. If that weren't enough, scientists are baffled because 
they *CANNOT* make matter without anti-matter and they can't understand why.

There is also the Schrodinger's Cat paradox but I can't accept it and won't 
include it in the list of undeniable reasons on principle. If I can't 
accept it, I have no right to expect you to and I believe that using it in 
such a way is an insult to the God I believe in. Those are my three 
reasons. As I have stated I will keep looking for more because three just 
isn't enough when there have to be clues everywhere to find. It doesn't 
feel right to just assume that I've found the only three pieces of 
evidence. Three is enough scientifically to support a theory as a fact but 
there just has to be more to find.
comments.author: DarkPegasus87

my personal string of thoughts. It is true that science doesn't yet know 
everything about everything. Scientists come up with theories which are 
often proven wrong or will be proved wrong in the future. So, it is not 
very wise to believe everything scientists say until solid proof is a fact. 
Also, if we want to pass judgement on science, we should somehow become 
scientific ourselves, in order to be able to understand what they talk 
about and if we have some knowledge, we may find flaws in their theories. 
Let me give you an example of what I mean. In the documentary, we saw jets 
of energy escaping from the center of the black holes. This means that 
black holes cannot hold infinate amout of energy in their structure. When 
the gothered energy reaches the limit, the black hole sends it back to 
space. Considering that a black hole alone, which is only an invisible dot 
in the vastness of space, can't keep endless amouts of energy, makes me 
think that the big bang is an imposible theory, because all the energy of 
the universe cannot be contained in a bubble the size of a pinhead. The 
energy jets of the black holes, tell us that there's a limit in with 
holding energy. So, science better come up with another theory of how the 
universe was made. ﻿

comments.text:
Our Milky Way may harbor millions of black holes... the ultra dense 
remnants of dead stars. But now, in the universe far beyond our galaxy, 
there's evidence of something far more ominous. A breed of black holes that 
has reached incomprehensible size and destructive power. Just how large, 
and violent, and strange can they get?

A new era in astronomy has revealed a universe long hidden to us. High-tech 
instruments sent into space have been tuned to sense high-energy forms of 
light -- x-rays and gamma rays -- that are invisible to our eyes and do not 
penetrate our atmosphere. On the ground, precision telescopes are equipped 
with technologies that allow them to cancel out the blurring effects of the 
atmosphere. They are peering into the far reaches of the universe, and into 
distant caldrons of light and energy. In some distant galaxies, astronomers 
are now finding evidence that space and time are being shattered by 
eruptions so vast they boggle the mind.

We are just beginning to understand the impact these outbursts have had on 
the universe: On the shapes of galaxies, the spread of elements that make 
up stars and planets, and ultimately the very existence of Earth. The 
discovery of what causes these eruptions has led to a new understanding of 
cosmic history. Back in 1995, the Hubble space telescope was enlisted to 
begin filling in the details of that history. Astronomers selected tiny 
regions in the sky, between the stars. For days at a time, they focused 
Hubble's gaze on remote regions of the universe. 

These hubble Deep Field images offered incredibly clear views of the cosmos 
in its infancy. What drew astronomers' attention were the tiniest galaxies, 
covering only a few pixels on Hubble's detector. Most of them do not have 
the grand spiral or elliptical shapes of large galaxies we see close to us 
today. 

Instead, they are irregular, scrappy collections of stars. The Hubble Deep 
Field confirmed a long-standing idea that the universe must have evolved in 
a series of building blocks, with small galaxies gradually merging and 
assembling into larger ones.﻿

+Alex Ashot Well, there is time as we measure it's passing on earth (more 
of a concept than a actual thing), & then there is space/time which is a 
bit tricky to try to describe without writing a book.

From the moment the Big Bang took place, the universe has bee spreading 
outwards from the point where the event took place, which also created 
space/time.

A over simplistic way to envision this would be to take a pail of pure 
water & drop some oil onto it's surface.

Slowly, the oil will spread to cover the entire surface no matter how large 
it may be, this is space/time, only unlike the pail of water, the big bang 
created to pail & water into which it spread.

There was nothing here, not even time or space, so we have something coming 
from nothing & spreading out into nothing.

comments.text:
+twocents Some of these responses address what would disprove scientific 
theories in general, and some address what would specifically disprove 
evolution, and Sagan also addresses what I said earlier about keeping our 
minds open because we do not know what will be discovered in the future. 
 Most have addressed the issue multiple times and at different levels (the 
responses given here are generally aimed at the general populous), but I 
will only list one or two quotes from each.

"We would need just one piece of evidence.  We would need the fossil that 
swam from one layer to another.  We would need evidence that the universe 
is not expanding.  We would need evidence that the stars appear to be far 
away but they're not.  We would need evidence that rock layers can somehow 
form in just 4,000 years instead of the extraordinary amount [of time].  We 
would need evidence that somehow you can reset atomic clocks and keep 
neutrons from becoming protons.  Bring on any of those things and you would 
change me immediately."

-Bill Nye, debate with Ken Ham


“Evolution could so easily be disproved if just a single fossil turned up 
in the wrong date order. Evolution has passed this test with flying 
colours.”

- Richard Dawkins, The Greatest Show on Earth: The Evidence for Evolution


"However, the broad lines of descent are so clear that evolution would at 
once be disproved if the skeleton of a man, a horse, or a bird were 
discovered imbedded in a coal seam."

- John Haldane, What I Require From Life


"Scientists are usually careful to characterize the vertical status of 
their attempts to understand the world - ranging from conjectures and 
hypotheses, which are highly tentative, all the way up to laws of Nature 
which are repeatedly and systematically confirmed through many 
interrogations of how the world works. But even laws of Nature are not 
absolutely certain. There may be new circumstances never before examined - 
inside black holes, say, or within the electron, or close to the speed of 
light - where even our vaunted laws of Nature break down and, however valid 
they may be in ordinary circumstances, need correction."

- Carl Sagan, The Dragon in my Garage

"...whatever I would tell you, where we would be in space or something like 
that, is bound to be, through the arguments on the idea that unless we 
destroy ourselves, overtaken by scientific ideas and technological 
developments that I haven’t a ghost of a chance of foreseeing."

- Carl Sagan, ‘Wonder and Skepticism’ CSICOP 1994 Keynote


While I do not have a specific quote from Darwin, both because he addresses 
the issue over several chapters in multiple books and also because I am too 
lazy to page through his books, one of the tenets of his theory of 
evolution by natural selection is the heritability of traits (i.e. they are 
passed on from 'parents' to 'offspring').  Neither the mechanisms nor 
mathematical evidence was available to Darwin (he was unaware of Mendel's 
work), so he spent the larger part of his latter years trying to discover 
the evidence to support it.  Several times he expresses concern that 
evidence to the contrary (i.e. that select traits are NOT genetically 
inherited by offspring) would render his theory obsolete.  This can most 
clearly be seen in "The Variation of Animals and Plants under 
Domestication", in which he so *nearly* rediscovers the work of Mendel 
using his own data.  Sorry I can't be more specific with this...

comments.text:
You have it right.  The further you look back in space, the further you 
look in time.  Those stars and structures we see in deep space with the 
hubble telescope are no longer there, they have changed into something else 
by now. What we see is what the universe looked like then.

We cannot see quite all the way back to the big bang because for a period 
of time after the big bang the universe was so hot it was a plasma, which 
is impermeable to electromagnectic radiation (light, xrays, radio waves, 
etc). After a while, matter cooled enough to for electromagnetic radiation 
to propagate.  I think that period is something like 100K years. As the 
universe cooled and expanded, so did the radiation. It shows up as 
background microwave radiation.  We detected it back in the 60's and mapped 
it a few times since then.

comments.text:
There's a mistake in this video-black holes do have limits. A black hole 
takes in matter and gradually releases it as energy (which are basically 
the same thing by Einstein's formula E=MC2) in two jet streams hundreds of 
light years long,sometimes called vaporisation. The bigger the black 
hole,the faster it vaporises. Many black holes only avoid this by keeping 
on replenishing themselves, therefore they grew super-massive in the early 
history of the universe. If it kept gobbling more than it released, only 
then will it be infinite. So if a black hole ate up all of the Universe, it 
would have to release it as energy.﻿

comments.author: Emily Ocean

comments.text:
Our Milky Way may harbor millions of black holes... the ultra dense 
remnants of dead stars. But now, in the universe far beyond our galaxy, 
there's evidence of something far more ominous. A breed of black holes that 
has reached incomprehensible size and destructive power. Just how large, 
and violent, and strange can they get?

A new era in astronomy has revealed a universe long hidden to us. High-tech 
instruments sent into space have been tuned to sense high-energy forms of 
light -- x-rays and gamma rays -- that are invisible to our eyes and do not 
penetrate our atmosphere. On the ground, precision telescopes are equipped 
with technologies that allow them to cancel out the blurring effects of the 
atmosphere. They are peering into the far reaches of the universe, and into 
distant caldrons of light and energy. In some distant galaxies, astronomers 
are now finding evidence that space and time are being shattered by 
eruptions so vast they boggle the mind.

We are just beginning to understand the impact these outbursts have had on 
the universe: On the shapes of galaxies, the spread of elements that make 
up stars and planets, and ultimately the very existence of Earth. The 
discovery of what causes these eruptions has led to a new understanding of 
cosmic history. Back in 1995, the Hubble space telescope was enlisted to 
begin filling in the details of that history. Astronomers selected tiny 
regions in the sky, between the stars. For days at a time, they focused 
Hubble's gaze on remote regions of the universe. 

These hubble Deep Field images offered incredibly clear views of the cosmos 
in its infancy. What drew astronomers' attention were the tiniest galaxies, 
covering only a few pixels on Hubble's detector. Most of them do not have 
the grand spiral or elliptical shapes of large galaxies we see close to us 
today. 

Instead, they are irregular, scrappy collections of stars. The Hubble Deep 
Field confirmed a long-standing idea that the universe must have evolved in 
a series of building blocks, with small galaxies gradually merging and 
assembling into larger ones.﻿

Listen up, or just read carefully... all you hear about astronomy or any 
sciences really, are theories. A theory is something backed by evidence but 
is open to change based on new information. This video is explaining what 
we believe to have happened, but is still theory. I tend to lean towards 
the side of optimism. I try to believe that the more powerful brains on our 
planet have made some accurate theories about the universe and will 
continue to form these theories with our new discoveries. Who knows? 
Stephen hawking and many other geniuses may be wrong. Could be right on 
track though. Optimism aside, I'm not sure we'll ever know the truth, but 
it is fun to try and find out.

Also, I personally feel that if black holes are the master architects of 
our universe, they may also be the end of it too, but that is not more than 
my own opinion.﻿

Keep in mind that the majority of this documentary is pure speculation. We 
still don't even understand the basics of how space is evolving, somehow 
the expansion of the universe seems to be accelerating but we don't know 
why. We say it's due to "dark energy" but no one has any idea what that is. 
The truth is we don't know how forces act over cosmic distances. We can 
barely even model stars correctly let alone entire galaxies or galaxy 
clusters. In fact even black holes themselves are unproven at this point﻿

comments.text:
We have never directly observed black holes. We have observed strong radio 
sources which current theories suggest must be coming from black holes. 
This does not mean they are "proven", they could be anything. (It's very 
likely they are black holes, but we don't really know)

And we cannot model dark matter because we don't understand how it's 
distributed. Some models suggest the dark matter must be in a ring around 
each galaxy. Some say differently. Nowadays they're saying that 98% of the 
mass in the universe is dark matter (most likely it's subatomic particles). 
How is this dark matter exchanged in a galactic collision? What effect does 
this dark matter have on black holes?

We don't know. All the things that we think we know are based on 
predictions and models. But the longer a theory sits and festers without 
observational evidence, the more crazy and disjointed from reality it 
becomes. Just look at what happened to string theory. It used to be the 
leading frontier of science, and now it's basically fallen flat on it's 
face.
comments.author: fluff125

comments.text:
Through computer simulation we can model the behavior of star formation, 
super nova, galaxy formation and galaxy collisions extremely accurately. 
Black holes are also a proven fact. The fact that we do not currently know 
what the mechanisms of dark matter and dark energy are, we can, again quite 
accurately, model their effects.

This isn't the 70's fella.

comments.text:
There's two types of people in this world. There's those with the universal 
scientific mindset, who accept that they don't always have the answers but 
vow to keep looking for them whatever the cost, and those who find it 
easier to stop looking, sit in their comfort zones for their entire lives, 
never question anything, and accept what they are told on the premise that 
it sounds so good that it must be true.

The paradoxical thing is that the latter party will question those with 
scientific mindsets, and not those who think like themselves. They are 
willing to point out the flaws in science without contributing to it's 
advancement in any way.

The problem is that we are human. Our brains are not meant to function to 
imagine massive numbers, or infinite weights, because that information 
doesn't really contribute to our survival.

We have a limited capacity for knowledge. We're stuck on a mote of dust, on 
an outpost that for all we know might be the only habitable mote of dust 
we'll ever know. We're incredibly small and stupid, and the universe is 
incredibly large and incomprehensible. It's easy to see how science can 
sound bleak next to the idea that "we were chosen people who were put here 
for a reason by God". But it doesn't feel bleak to me- actually, it's 
amazing.

Here's my mindset on life-

For some incredible reason, I was given the temporary gift to understand 
this beautiful anomaly that is the universe. I don't have all the answers, 
I accept that I never will, but for the time I'm alive, I will learn 
something new about this place every day. To me, that sounds much much more 
exciting than the idea that "God" is watching me and telling me what I can 
and cannot do before he judges me for an eternity.

It takes away my need to fear what I can and cannot question, and that is 
why I am a scientist.﻿

You're sitting comfortably in your home, playing games on your 
computer/console, watching videos on Youtube. When you're thirsty, you have 
your choice of beverage. When you're hungry, you have a fridge full of 
food. Tomorrow, you might be going shopping or to a restaurant. When you 
step outside, the first thing you hear isn't the high pitched whining of a 
drone.

some tragic Hollywood story?? Not that I can condone Islamic 
fundamentalism, but dismissing these people as "crazy" or "retards" is

ignorance on the part of an America that didn't pay the slightest bit of 
attention to what was happening in the world.

exist outside where people struggle, fight, and die.

Black holes do not and cannot exist with our current understanding of 
cosmology.  Even theoretical mathematics precludes their existence.  They 
cannot exist within another universe and cannot coexist with another black 
hole.  You don't need an advanced degree in physics to understand.  
Unfortunately, today's science is all headlines proclaiming proof of 
theories that don't begin to give them validation.

Knee-jerk reaction will be to dismiss my claims because that couldn't 
possibly happen in science.  Science is truth.  Arguably, it may be the 
best way to find truths, however, we have scientists in areas of great 
influence who do not revere truth as much as most.  Whether delusional or 
egoic, those who have a vested interest in the current paradigm are 
manipulating reality to conform to their perspective.﻿

comments.text:
Any theory that mixes Event Horizon Black Holes and Dark Matter is doomed 
to fail. That didn't even make much sense, it's just science-buzzword-soup.

Dark Matter is (supposedly) non-baryonic matter which adds an extra 
gravitational push to galactic rotation to make the standard equations of 
gravity work on that scale. It only "exists" because the equations we use 
need extra matter to spit out the right answer on a galactic scale, not 
because we've proven that it exists.

As a point of fact, I don't believe it does exist, and view the amount of 
so-called Dark Matter as a marker of how far our equations are just out of 
line with reality. Dark Energy even more so.

intertwined and the more heavy and dense an object is, the slower time goes 
around it. What is quite certain though is that the tiny spot a black hole 
is a created in is just the compact matter in it. the event horizon has 
only been the matter of mystery because we can't see beyond it, and hence 
created a whole storm of speculation, but currently with our understanding 
it should be just super compact matter in an incredibly small space (can't 
be any smaller than the plank length though), but our math is far from 
being perfect and more information is bound to come up at some point, until 
then, you'd best stick with what is known instead giving credit to pure 
speculations.

comments.text:
Condensing the matter is the key you can think of all the matter inside a 
black hole, now, imagine instead all that mass is not packed as close 
together, but, is seperated out into a giant glass cloud. A nebula, from 
which stars originally form from. If flying through said nebula, you 
wouldn't become trapped, its unquestionably a result of its incredible 
compression. In fact, microscopic black holes exist, made from very little 
total mass. They evaporate, just as larger black holes do, but much much 
faster. At any rate, you really can find the truth for yourself by 
researching gravity itself. Its interesting to note that as you leave the 
center or an objects gravitational field, the strength of that field 
decreases as the square of your distance. Its a direct function of 
distance, so, if you are 2x further away, the field is acting on you with 
about 1/4th the force. That equation works in reverse as well, so, the fact 
that the force increases as a square, not linearly will explain why there 
seems to be that criticle mass/compression ratio for objects of all sizes. 
I know I probably should avoid generalizations such as saying, for all 
objects, but, I think for simplicity's sake I'll use some in this example. 
Thanks for the replays and if I'm wrong here, someone feel free to correct 
me.

comments.text:
you sir, though very close, need to do your research on how gravity works. 
Our galaxy would have less gravitational force if spread apart more, but 
only due to the fact that the strength of gravitational force is inversely 
related to the distance between all the masses. Meaning that when the 
distance increases by say double, the force of gravity is decreased to a 
quarter of the original. So saying that condensing something would give it 
a higher gravitational acceleration is false. It would have the same 
gravitational acceleration, but with the more distance between you and the 
object, in this case the black hole, the less gravitational force you feel 
because of, like I stated earlier, Newton's inverse square law, where the 
gravitational force on an object because of another object, is inversely 
proportional to the distance squared, and directly proportional to the 
product of the two masses and the universal gravitational constant(Which 
only exists because everything in the universe has gravity and pulls on 
each other with their gravities, therefore the outside universe has gravity 
and is in fact, pulling on us with a force, though it is extremely small. 
Not small enough to be negligible, but small nonetheless)
comments.author: Spencer Grundy

comments.text:
+Steams Nightcore \( ^^,)\ I feel that Religion is not the same as 
spirituality. Religion was made initially to try and explain and 
rationalize spirituality and unfortunately, the perceived 'differences' 
between people were emphasized instead of what is common, and thus 
conflicts arose between the various religions .
The two should not be confused in my opinion. A static, retrogressive 
belief system cannot move along with or adapt successfully to Change, the 
constant universal dynamic.
Few realize that before Religion, for example in pre-Dynastic Egypt, there 
were only a set of Cosmic Ideals - universal guidelines, not fear-based and 
restrictive rules and regulations; and personal and intimate relationships 
with their own gods and goddesses, which personify the forces of Nature.
To my mind there is absolutely no contradiction in terms between science 
and individual, Nature-based forms of spirituality.
The ancients certainly never saw any distinction, as for example Astronomy 
and (original) Astrology were one discipline. The Sumerians worked with 
star charts, and Thoth, the God of Wisdom, is responsible for introducing 
the concept of cyclical time - without which, civilization would not be 
possible and really things would fall apart as we would have no means of 
reference to 'hold onto'. If one looks at the Native Americans, there was 
no organized religion, yet they are a very spiritual people in tune with 
the currents of Nature.
Really the only conflict I personally see between Science and Pagan Nature 
spirituality is some of the unnecessary and harmful methods used in 
research, for example with vivisection; and the wrongful use of technology 
to advance weapons and precipitate conflict between people..
We see all life as sacred, and certainly do not believe in either an evil 
devil or jealous god of punishment.Viva Science and Nature!
Blessed Be
comments.author: Billy Green

comments.text:
As long as they feed, they will continue to spin and grow larger. Even when 
not feeding these objects can continue to spin for billions of years before 
it shows signs of slowing down and even then the speeds are near the speed 
of light. ( thus why light cannot escape them and light is the fastest 
speed you can get in the Universe ) The larger they grow the more likely it 
will eventually become a small galaxy dominating nearby stars and clusters. 
However there is an end to these objects. When the Universe expands into 
darkness it means that galaxies gravity's can no longer influence each or 
merge with each other. They are so far apart that gravity essentially dies 
and everything is flung apart. Black Holes will be the ONLY objects left

+Steve Edwards The laws of physics breakdown at the centre of a black hole. 
We simply don't know what happens at the singularity. It could well 
"disappear from the Universe", but that is just speculation. Also we 
presently can do nothing to stop a black hole (we can't even get close to 
one), but who knows where we will be in a thousand (or million) years from 
now - technology-wise.

Also a black hole does physically exist - it is made from matter. Matter 
that has been condensed to a ridiculously small size. It's energy comes 
from the gravity created by this density. There is however still much we 
don't know about them.

What the LHC dose happens in our own atmosphere constantly by close to 
light speed fragments from space hitting our atmosphere. Obviously we can 
not measures the impacts there, ergo the LHC...

There is zero risk of creating a black hole that would destroy the Earth 
because if it was. Earth wouldnt have been around long enough for the first 
human to see a ray of light.

However, IF Hawkins radiation is true. The LHC can produce microscopic 
black holes that will instantly vaporize. IF they manage to detect that 
vaporization it will prove Hawkins radiation. It will also mean that even 
super large black holes will not last forever. Most likely be the last 
things to "die" in the Universe by very very slowly radiating away their 
mass.

Which is probably good because a Galaxy sized black hole losing mass too 
fast would be like a spinning disk throwing marbles as it spun. The marbles 
being planets and stars at the edge of its Galaxy when its black hole mass 
lost gravitational pull because of loss of mass.

A black hole does NOT have infinite density; I believe you have misread 
something. That matter is crushed almost out of existence due to immense 
gravitational forces does not mean it has reached infinite density; the 
word 'almost' is correct. Something has stopped the gravitational collapse 
from proceeding further. It is this 'something' that is not yet understood.

There has been plenty of evidence to support the existence of what we have 
termed 'black holes', and a Scottish scientist in Australia has witnessed a 
supernova birthing a black hole. They DO exist, we just don't know for 
certain what a black hole actually IS.

comments.text:
Nonsense from the start. There is no proof for the existence of black holes 
and the forces and emissions of galactic nuclei can all be explained 
without the need for an impossibly massive unobservable imaginary object. 
X-Rays, Gamma Rays etc can all be created in the lab using electricity and 
by using electromagnetic fields to accelerate and collide particles. 
Observations prove that there are vast electromagnetic fields and electric 
currents at the centers of galaxies. Electromagnetic fields naturally 
rotate (as do galaxies) and the vast electromagnetic fields could easily 
account for the emissions from galactic centers known as galactic jets, 
emissions that weren't accounted for in black hole theory until they were 
observed. Up until then it was said that nothing could escape a 'black 
hole', when the vast X-Ray emissions from galactic nuclei were discovered 
'scientists' (I use the term loosely) came up with new untestable theories 
to explain these emissions rather than giving up on the nonsense that is 
black hole theory.﻿

comments.text:

ALL 'scientific knowledge' was theory at one point.  Television, among 
other more useful inventions is the product of ideas which were  deemed 
useless by many.  We have no shortage of naysayers like yourself and its 
only the optimistic that solve problems, so please either assist or desist. 

We have reached no perfect solutions yet (nuclear fission power generation, 
for example), but we need new ideas to find better approaches to the 
problems at hand (nuclear fusion, on the other hand, has no toxic 
byproducts and produces a net energy gain).  So lets not be ignorant and 
give up on all efforts just because one approach doesn't work.  If you are 
so passionate about helping, please create your own ideas and quit shooting 
others' down.  I suggest you pursue a career in engineering, where we find 
practical applications for the theories of others.  I should hope you've 
worked on your attitude though, should I see you in the field.

comments.text:
+streuthmonkey1
First of all, you are correct in expressing that Tesla was an enormous 
asset to our understanding of electromagnetism and so I do not wish to 
downplay his work.  He was truly genius and endlessly pursued each and 
every of his ideas without hesitation, many of which he took no credit for 
and cared only for their impact on the world as a whole.  Despite this, we 
must be careful not to downplay the contributions of those who chose to 
look further ahead and beyond instant application.  These men and women are 
not any less important to us simply because we don't understand or apply 
their contributions personally.  Einstein was a great thinker and so has 
proposed a relationship describing the world around and beyond us.  While 
we use some of his theories today, others may only be proven far beyond our 
lifetimes but that does not mean they are any less important.  Recently, it 
was confirmed to within 5sigma that extreme gravitational fields can 
polarize electromagnetic waves, as was observed with some that have only 
just reached us and date back to moments after the rapid universal 
expansion we call the Big Bang had begun.  This discovery, as predicted by 
Einstein, is ground breaking and though we are far from the technological 
understanding that could use and manipulate this relationship, it has still 
helped us to further understand the world around us.  This is the primary 
goal of science.  It is for the engineers to apply this knowledge so that 
we may improve our quality of life. 

Speaking of which, as an Engineer myself, let me counter your 
counterarguments:

1) The time dilation between the satellites and earth is NOT constant and 
would take far too long to determine by trial and error.

2) When I said improvement of 'Semiconductor Optimization Techniques' I was 
speaking of the unpredictable nature of electrons and the effects of 
quantum tunneling in which electrons defy potential energy walls and 
relocate to where they aren't supposed to be.  The detriment of this effect 
may have been noticed but it would have taken a remarkably bright 
individual to derive the relationships that describe this as Einstein, 
Heisenberg and others did.  So, yes, technically and Electrical Engineer 
could have discovered these properties of subatomic particles but then he 
would simply have been the next Einstein.  For the most part, it is easier 
for us to focus on the applications of what we know then to work in 
abstract theory, so we'll leave that to the savants.

3) The LHC falls under the category of knowledge that adds to our 
understanding, though it many not be immediately applicable.  However, it 
is always worth the investment if there is something to be learned.  We 
invested enormous sums in the space program in the 50s and 60s, and they 
succeeded in landing us on the moon.  Just because the outcome of the 
investment is uncertain, does not mean the risk isn't worth taking.

Finally, I'm not sure you understand that our understandings are built upon 
the discoveries of others.  Neither Einstein nor Tesla could have 
contributed anything if it weren't for the work of others before them, much 
of which was of no use at the time of its discovery.  Without the passion 
and vigor of those who dedicate their lives to endeavors that seem futile 
to most, we would be nowhere.

Here are some of the practical applications and inventions thought of by 
Nikola Tesla who described the work that physicists such as Einstein did as 
meta-physics, an accurate description. 1. Discovered Alternating Current
2. Developed and used florescent bulbs in his lab some 40 years before 
industry "invented" them.
3. Invented radio
4. Worked on the development of practical uses of X-rays. Produced the 
first x-ray image in the United States when he attempted to obtain an image 
of Mark Twain with the vacuum tube. Instead of showing Twain, the resulting 
image showed the screw for adjusting the camera lens  Later, Tesla managed 
to obtain images of the human body, which he called shadowgraphs. Tesla 
sent his images to Wilhelm Conrad Roentgen shortly after Roentgen published 
his discovery on November 8, 1895. Although Tesla gave Roentgen full credit 
for the finding, Roentgen congratulated Tesla on his sophisticated images, 
wondering how he had achieved such impressive results. Moreover, Tesla 
described some clinical benefits of x-rays—for example, determination of 
foreign body position and detection of lung diseases (8)—noting that denser 
bodies were more opaque to the rays
5. Invented remote control
6.Invented the electric motor
7. Invented Laser
8. Invented wireless communications

Einstein was around at the same time as Tesla, what did he invent. What

+DXMediaTV Well that was just a whole mish-mash of fallacies that sought to 
strawman a valid question from Marty Grof. 

Person A: There's a spider on my head.

A: No, no, you can't touch it.
B: Did it come from an egg?
A: No, it's just there.
B: Okay then let me x-ray it.
A: No, you can't x ray it either
B: Okay I'll use infrared

suppose to know it's there

it's exempt from natural laws.

"The question is tricky because it sneaks in the false assumption that God 
came from somewhere and then asks where that might be."

Your response and belief in God is tricky because you have the false 
assumption that there needs to be a creator for there to be matter and 
energy. That is called begging the question.

The truth is that you don't know and God does not exist or in the least is 
extremely unlikely, because there is no such thing as a square-circle, an 
invisible color, or an omnipotent, omniscient being. 

Again there is no reason there can't be more than one God
And a being without form, an intelligence without matter, and a deity that 
exists outside space and time would effectively define nonexistence.

"God is the uncaused Being that caused everything else to come into 
existence."

Everything observed in nature has a cause, and yet you remove causation 
from God. 

You can only gather information from your senses, because it's all you 
have. God can not be proven using sense or machines or logic. But God can 
be disproven with logic.

You seek to use sophistry to back up your ideas, which was a jumble of a 
non-arguments for the existence of God.

I hope you at least don't follow the Bible and only believe in a primordial

more ridiculous.

And I do not seek to explain the origin of the universe because I do not

comments.author: VIGILANTIA

comments.text:
+Marty Grof The question is tricky because it sneaks in the false 
assumption that God came from somewhere and then asks where that might be. 
The answer is that the question does not even make sense. It is like 
asking, “What does blue smell like?” Blue is not in the category of things 
that have a smell, so the question itself is flawed. In the same way, God 
is not in the category of things that are created or caused. God is 
uncaused and uncreated—He simply exists.

How do we know this? We know that from nothing, nothing comes. So, if there 
were ever a time when there was absolutely nothing in existence, then 
nothing would have ever come into existence. But things do exist. 
Therefore, since there could never have been absolutely nothing, something 
had to have always been in existence. That ever-existing thing is what we 
call God. God is the uncaused Being that caused everything else to come 
into existence. God is the uncreated Creator who created the universe and 
everything in it.

Read more: http://www.gotquestions.org/who-created-God.html#ixzz2tEpE8ySg

comments.text:
1. "...may harbor millions of black holes..." [0:37] is off by a factor of 
thousands: 30% of all stars today formed shortly after the Big Bang, during 
the Supernova Chaining Era wherein large stars were the preference in the 
relatively-still-dense cosmic gas... And that, means, *billions*, of black 
holes in our galaxy halo that can't escape because: the average SN-core 
exit-velocity merely bumps its galactic-orbit-velocity to change direction 
and radius 30%...

2. Astronomers today generally explain that Time stops at the Schwarzschild 
radius in our outside-perspective; And that, means the entire innards of 
Black Holes are already frozen solid (to us)--making them, *Black Hole 
Bottoms*, not "holes" per sé and, not so black....﻿
comments.author: Raymond K Petry

comments.text:
1. Large stars were preferred in the early cosmos–a fact of 'SNR shockwave 
meets tenuously-dense cosmic gas' reducing the dimensionality of molecular 
clouds to 2D flattened and mashing smaller clumps into larger: whence more 
SN, larger SN, and proportionally more BH's than neutron stars as 
SN-remnants...
2. In ordinary 3D molecular clouds, 1% become SN-potential giant stars: 
That's 1-4 *billion* among the 100-400 billion stars in the Milky Way... 
(2D means *more billions*)
3. BH's have no preference for swallowing except small BH's take small 
gulps...and if BH's can merge then so can neutrons stars which thereby 
produce *more* BH's...
4. Only the BH's formed very near the core would by-half remain near the 
core: the other-half and the rest of the *billions* fling-about-up-and-down 
the galaxy, forever...
5. Our Milky Way core has a 4.2 *million* M☉ BH bobbing-about, so...equally 
many were flung out of the core, adding to the *billions* in the rest of 
the galaxy...
comments.author: Raymond K Petry

comments.text:
Distance is measured in light years, for the most part. Light moves at 299 
792 458 metres per second. That is proven fact.
1 light year = 9.4605284 × 10(to the power of 15) meters.

The reason we call it a light year is because it is the distance light 
travels in one year.

In the case of measuring how far a star is; It comes down to triangulation 
within a roughly 6 month period. Now, the final number is an estimation, 
but it's still a pretty good number to go on. :)

comments.text:
The singularity is just a point in the mathematical equation where the 
density function goes to infinity. When this happens the equation is no 
longer useful to describe what is happening with matter. A new equation is 
required but that equation is not known yet. That is what the search for a 
theory of quantum gravity is all about. 

Speculation about the form of matter inside a black hole is just that, 
speculation. It is precisely because we do not know what state the matter 
is in that we cannot say the density is infinite and that it exists at a 
point. It doesn't need to be infinitely dense to form a black hole, just 
sufficiently dense to have an escape velocity greater than c.﻿

holographic principle).
