comments.text:
Interesting theory, but I doubt that is the case. A black hole just has an 
extremely large amount of mass in an infinitly small area. Since mass has 
gravity it holds itself there which is what makes it so small. if something 
were to enter the event horizon and gets "sucked up" it would just add to 
its mass causing it to get stronger. It is not really a hole in space. But, 
it is a hole in time. We do not fully understand the passage of time, but 
we do know that gravity does affect time, more gravity = more time. That is 
why when something enters a black hole it appears to slow down when in 
reality they are accelerating. To us the object in the black hole would 
take hundreds of years whereas to that object it would take merely a few 
minutes to reach the center since the objects perception of time is not 
changed. This could be a way to make a time machine!

comments.text:
That's the thing, we don't know, but that's what is so amazing about the 
universe. We know so much but yet so little, the presentations in this 
video are just artist renderings and some blurry pictures thrown in to show 
what scientists look like and what they THINK they actually act, look, 
react, etc. In terms of the actual Universe, we know nothing, we are but a 
young clump of atoms known as animals that can think and ask these 
questions. If the Universe was a school ready to begin class, we would have 
just came out of our mothers' womb. We use what we know so far to calculate 
all these answers with mathematics and our basic understanding of Science. 
Every scientist has never said they "have the right answer" they just have 
an answer that fits their criteria to gain a better understanding of the 
question. Even if we are wrong about everything, Math, Physics, the 
Universe, the Solar System, or even Space itself as a whole, we would learn 
from those mistakes and correct them to what we believe is the RIGHT 
answer. This video is just representing what we THINK the Universe looks 
like, but we could be wrong, but that is the complexity, mysteriousness, 
and wonders of the Universe.

explosions (so i've been told). This dark matter went into another plain of 
the universe. Black holes could be an entrance to this plain. The fact that 
black holes have such a significant gravity could be because when you are 
in a space ship and you have a hole in a space ship, it sucks out anything 
through it. Etc when you have even a tiny hole if you're in the vacuum of 
space, it'll tear open the inside and suck everything out, what if this is 
happening with black holes? Just my theory on how black holes work

comments.text:
+Dennis Kautz
Mate, you don't even know what scientists claim Dark Matter is, and you use 
a link to an Electric Universe Proponent to show that Dark Matter is an "Ad 
hoc fix to the Big Bang".

Dark matter was first inferred from the Galactic rotation-problem, and 
later shown to have different properties from normal visible matter, in 
colliding galaxy-clusters like the Bullet Cluster.

"Recently, the European Southern Observatory (ESO) in Paranal, Chile 
announced that there is “no evidence for dark matter in a large volume 
around the Sun".

Well what do you think that tells us?

Well naturally that the region of space that our solar-system inhabits is 
devoid of Dark Matter (again, demonstrating that dark matter has different 
properties than visible matter).

As for the Electric Universe. We've already done calculations, for 
situations where electromagnetism keeps charged particles in orbits similar 
to solarsystems. They're unstable. Electromagnetism isn't what keeps the 
Earth, nor the Sun, nor the Galaxy in orbit.
comments.author: MrFalconfly

comments.text:
+MrFalconfly
In regard to your assertion that dark matter, dark energy and black holes 
do not have anything to do with the big bang.

https://www.thunderbolts.info/wp/2012/04/19/dark-and-dead/

"Dark matter is supposed to be what holds the Universe together. However, 
modern telescopes are not able to see it because it does not interact with 
luminous matter, except gravitationally. Since galaxies spin through the 
cosmos, as well as move away from each other, they “must be” bound by dark 
matter gravity stitches, since there is not enough normal matter to account 
for the mass that they must possess in order to behave the way they do.

Galaxy clusters, for example, should have slowed down considerably over the 
last few billion years of space-time expansion and not maintained such wild 
velocities. Some galaxies, say astronomers, are moving so fast that they 
are hard on the heels of light speed.
It is often written in the popular press that dark matter makes up “25% of 
the Universe” or that dark energy makes up “75% of the rest of the 
Universe.” To anyone familiar with plasma physics, it is well known that 
plasma makes up 99.99% of the Universe. The amount of gravitational mass 
invented to save conventional theories is the same as the ionized plasma in 
an Electric Universe that is overlooked.

Recently, the European Southern Observatory (ESO) in Paranal, Chile 
announced that there is “no evidence for dark matter in a large volume 
around the Sun.

...It is electric currents that drive galaxies and their stars. The 
magnetic vortices between large-scale Birkeland current filaments create 
galaxies. Birkeland currents have a longer-range attractive force than 
gravity, and diminish with the reciprocal of the distance rather than 
gravity’s square of the distance. That alone could account for the 
anomalous movement of stars as they revolve around galactic cores.

The flow of electricity through plasma in space initiates the effects that 
are seen through space-based telescopes, confirming ground-based research. 
Electric currents in the cosmos and their associated magnetic fields should 
be our focus and not the search for that which can never be found.

“Plasma cosmology can demonstrate with simple physical principles the 
electrical formation and behavior of spiral galaxies and stars without 
recourse to hypothetical dark matter and black holes.” - Wal Thornhill
comments.author: Dennis Kautz

comments.text:
+Dennis Kautz
That might very well be the case.

That doesn't speak against "Dark Matter", simply because of how it's 
defined.

Dark Matter is defined as "Unknown mass that doesn't emit any EM radiation".

This isn't an ad hoc fix. It's an observation given a name.

As for " And just because matter does not follow the current model of 
cosmology, doesn't mean that it is dark energy, dark matter, black holes or 
an expanding universe."

Dark Matter has been observed to occupy regions differently from visible 
matter. That strongly suggests that it isn't us measuring the mass of 
visible matter wrongly, but us observing something we don't know.

Take a look at observations from the Bullet Cluster.

Most of the visible matter is in the middle of that cluster, but using 
gravitational lensing to map the mass distribution of the cluster we've 
been able to determine two "lobes" of Dark Matter on each side of the 
cluster (as if two galaxy-clusters have collided, resulting in most of the 
gas being collected at the center since gas interacts, but the dark matter 
passed through, since that doesn't interact).
comments.author: MrFalconfly

comments.author: MrFalconfly

comments.text:
+Dennis Kautz
Dark Matter, Dark Energy and Black holes have nothing to do with the Big 
Bang theory.

Black Holes were a logical deduction from Einstein's theory of General 
Relativity, later shown to be plausible, in that we see objects orbiting 
something that doesn't emit EM radiation.

Dark Matter was inferred from observations of galaxies. The math didn't add 
up. The visible matter wasn't enough to generate the mass of the galaxy. So 
we inferred that there was "something" there. What the "something" is, is 
yet to be discovered. Hence DARK Matter

Dark Energy was inferred from observations of the expansion of the 
universe. We knew the universe was expanding, but not at what rate. 
Theories suggested that either the expansion would continue at a steady 
rate, or slow down. However the expansion is accelerating, suggesting a 
force that's affecting the entire universe. What's generating this force is 
yet to be discovered. Hence DARK Energy.

None of this has anything to do with the viability of the Big Bang theory.
comments.author: MrFalconfly

Dark Matter: Unknown mass that doesn't emit any EM radiation (note,

+Rand Babs
Again.

A label, place on a yet to be discovered event.

We can clearly see that the universal expansion is accelerating, so that 
requires a force.

So let's just call that force "Dark Energy" for now, until we learn what it 
actually is (instead of calling it "that unidentified, universe-expansion 
accelerating force that seems to be tied with the age of the known 
universe").

Dark: Because we don't know what it is.

Energy: Because it's clearly some form of energy, since it accelerates the 
expansion of the universe.

comments.author: Rand Babs

comments.text:
+Rand Babs
That is a misrepresentation of the data.

We do see an effect that suggests large quantities of matter (which we call 
"dark matter") are distributed through the universe.

The issue isn't if "dark matter" exists (we can see the effects, so it most 
certainly does. Hell we've seen regions of space where visible matter, and 
"dark matter" have been distinguished from each other, like the Bullet 
Cluster), but what "dark matter" is.

Is it some exotic particles?

Is it some yet to be discovered heavy objects that doesn't emit EM 
radiation (like solitude black holes)?

Is it some form of attraction from a neighbor universe?

We don't know, and that's what makes it exiting.

Dark matter, isn't some bodge-job fix to make a theory work. It's a label 
on a yet to be discovered mechanism.

This is assuming that black holes are comprised of anti-matter, which they 
are not. The Schwarzschild radius is the formula to determine at what size 
to mass ratio would any object in the universe turn into a black hole. They 
are made of matter that has been condensed into an infinitely small point 
by gravity.

comments.text:
While this is mostly still true, the theory of general relativity doesn't 
work without black holes, but the theory itself works. I'm not assuming 
correlation implies causation but we have observed stellar orbits at the 
center of galaxies. Mainly stars orbiting an incredibly dense object which 
creates a powerful gravitational field as well as the gamma radiation 
emissions and X-ray emissions from these cosmic bodies. All evidence is 
conclusive that black holes exist
comments.author: Kha Zix

comments.text:
No, black and white holes are just an inevitability of Einsteins theory of 
general relativity, depending on how you arrange the formula you get a 
black hole which grows as it feeds or a white hole which is like a black 
hole running backwards in time. They are essentially the same thing, the 
only difference is what sign you apply to Einstein's field theories.
comments.author: Kha Zix

comments.text:
that is not necessarily true, in a sense, the universe can expand faster 
than the speed of light because the areas of the universe that are 
expanding contain no matter and therefore no mass. The idea that a mass 
cannot accelerate to the speed of light because of the infinite energy 
needed to maintain an increasing velocity doesn't apply to objects without 
mass since they don't require energy to maintain velocity.
comments.author: Kha Zix

comments.text:

comments.text:
we simply do not understand gravity well enough to introduce a law of 
gravity. We understand how it works in a practical sense, but we don't know 
exactly why it works. Don't bother arguing with me on that fact by the way, 
feel free to google till your heart is content, there is no explanation in 
science for the behavior of gravity because we don't understand it on an 
elementary level IE the particle responsible governing the force.
comments.author: Kha Zix

comments.text:
A scientific law is defined as something that CANNOT be broken. Because we 
don't fully understand the law of gravity (and more so over, do not 
understand or know which elementary particle governs gravity) it will 
remain a theory. There is no such thing as both a scientific law and 
theory. It is either one or the other. Conversely the three laws of 
thermodynamics are scientific law because we could test them infinitely in 
an infinite number of ways and get the same result.
comments.author: Kha Zix

You are thinking of expansion as the "stuff" within the universe moving 
apart. It's not the stuff moving (although it does move and in many cases, 
apart). It's the medium on which the stuff exists that is expanding, 
space-time itself. It is inflating. It is doing so at an increasingly rapid 
pace. This is why you can have a universe that is only 13ish billion years 
old, but have stuff WAY outside of our ability to see it. Expansion happens 
faster than light.

since it is relatively close to the viewer. For a frame of reference in 
order to get a sense of how fast light travels picture this, it takes light 
only about 1 second to travel the distance between the Earth and the moon. 
It took the Apollo missions about 3 days. Insane...

comments.text:
Basically, gravity sufficient to prevent light from escaping is not equal 
to infinite gravity. The difference between a regular black hole and a 
super massive black hole is their mass and the corresponding diameter of 
their event horizon. Every elliptical galaxy containing a super massive 
black hole is just an accretion disc which has formed around that 
gravitational center. That accretion disc may contain any number of smaller 
black holes and their accretion discs within it. Explained.
comments.author: wasack17

comments.text:
according to the maths the gravity is infinite at the singularity. Well 
that's what Michio Kaku said on a documentary I watched. It is part of the 
reason the math is suspect. I just felt that my observation is relevant in 
that context
comments.author: Arno Hayes

comments.text:
Gravity strong enough to prevent light from escaping is a characteristic of 
all black holes, but the ability to prevent light from escaping does not 
mean that their gravity is infinite. Light travels at ~186,000 mile per 
second. For a black hole to be a black hole, it simply needs to have 
gravity so strong that the required escape velocity of any object 
attempting to leave its gravitational pull at the event horizon exceeds the 
speed of light.
comments.author: wasack17

comments.text:
By the principle of Hawking Radiation, a black hole can eventually 
evaporate, and hence cease existing. The principle is that a set of 
particles, of opposing polarity, can form on the event horizon (following 
reletavity), with one falling back into the event horizon, while the other 
particle drifts off into space. This hence results in an energy loss in the 
black hole, thus decreasing its mass, hence eventually evaporating it. i 
may be wrong however, since this is just my lay-man understanding

gravitational radiation.

doesn't have the mass needed to collapse onto itself with the force needed

layers (planetary nebula) until it finally becomes a white dwarf, before 
ending it's entire life as a black dwarf.

comments.text:
Black holes are infinitely dense. What the video doesn't really explain is 
that they have a finite mass. Therefore The greater the amount of mass in a 
black hole, the greater the size, not necessarily the density. The more 
mass (matter) that falls into a black hole, The greater the diameter of the 
event horizon becomes. Think more on the line of volume = size rather than 
mass = density. Hope this helps.
comments.author: becknook1

super-massive, super-dense larger-than-star-sized object floating through 
space. The gravitational pull from this object is so strong that it bends

approached each other, one would overtake the smaller, but not much effect 
will be added.

universe. Make of that what you will.

But, let's say you have a ship capable of traveling at lightspeed, like you 
said. Being able to go that fast means you could enter into an orbit around 
a black hole that comes very, very close to the Event Horizon without the 
risk of falling in, and the nearer to the EH you get, the greater the 
relativistic effect, because spacetime is so distorted there. Supposedly, a 
single slingshot-type close maneuver around a black hole could potentially 
catapult you thousands or millions of years fwd.
comments.author: Tsurugi

comments.text:
Based on what I have read about black holes, gravity, and relativistic 
effects, I don't think there is a way to travel "through" a black hole. A 
black hole is not like a wormhole, it does not have an "exit" or an "other 
side". Think of a black hole as being a bottomless pit, rather than a 
tunnel. The Event Horizon of a black hole is the point at which the pull of 
its gravity exceeds the speed of light, so even if you can go lightspeed, 
you'd still be trapped inside if you crossed the EH.
comments.author: Tsurugi

There is a term in physics called the measurement problem. It is when an 
electron changes from a wave to a particle. It only changes when being 
observed or measured. It collapses from wave to particle. What does this 
mean? It means, everything is in the form of waves and our brain changes it 
into particle when we look at it. So, a black hole might not be a hole at 
all. It might not be round or black for that matter. In theory, everything 
is a waves until we view it. Thus, it would be a hologram.

since the earth has mass, therefore, a "universal" weight. A black hole 
happen when usually a star, or (possibly a even higher mass object) has too 
much mass, and the "Rug" can no longer support the

comments.author: John Galt

comments.text:
No, I mean that when we apply general relativity to the quantum mechanical 
solutions, we get nonsense results. We need quantum gravity (a field of 
gravitational perturbration on the quantum scales) to adequately describe 
what takes place at the singularity of a black hole. We do not have one. 
Black holes -- objects with enormous gravity that absorb all light and 
matter, do exist. They are likely not "infinite." Infinity is a sign that 
our physical theory is limited.
comments.author: John Galt

comments.text:
So with broken math, I assume you mean that the Droste-Hilbert solution of 
Einstein equations (describing a black hole) probably does not describe 
anything real in the physical world. Thus making this solution that lead to 
the black hole not accurate. The question if black holes exist or not, is 
not a mathematical one, but a physical question. It think it is necessary 
to rethink theory of the gravitational field. Have you ever explored the 
electric universe theory?
comments.author: ikwtif

comments.text:
There will always be crackpots in any field of science. Too much to debunk. 
Here is a good way to look at it: For a long time, black holes were "stupid 
talk." No one believed in them. Sure, they work mathematically. But we had 
no evidence. Slowly, a consensus was *earned* through scientific study. It 
wasn't just accepted in a week, or even years. It took a long time. ANY 
astronomer would love to be the person that discovered what black holes 
were and to disprove the current hypothesis.
comments.author: John Galt

It is absolutely amazing how well we already understand the events in 
the immediate vicinity of black holes without being able to directly 
observe these dark, heavy, but at the same time tiny anomalies in 
spacetime. *With the **+LISA Mission** we will finally clear the dust and 
can follow single stars on their way to the event horizon.* Everything 
which falls into a black hole will be our probe to map the gravitational 
field around these supermassive black holes. So we can test the very 
substance of General Relativity and will find out more about the mechanisms 
and features of these black holes.﻿

comments.text:
Denser matter. Once gravity reaches about 20,000 g's then matter becomes 
neutronium, meanwhile at 28,000 g's then it becomes a black hole. The 
heavier the black hole, the more dense it becomes. The "Black hole" is 
simply the event-horizon, i.e. the distance at which gravity is over 
28,000g's so that escape-velocity is higher than light-speed; all matter 
and energy outside that is the accretion-disc, most of which is ejected at 
the poles, while anything reaching the event horizon is sucked in.
comments.author: Jojo Dynamo

comments.text:
NOT if you used a warp-engine to counter the gravitational field. And the 
black hole only keeps light from escaping, not gravity, so the warp-engine 
an also be used to create a gravity-flux signal to communicate outside the 
event-horizon.

travel around the galaxy, but also between galaxies using the black holes 
at their centers; this would allow humans to explore the entire universe in

communications, using gravitational flux to both send and listen for 
signals. across long distances using similar methods. The larget the black 
hole, the longer the distance that can be spanned.
comments.author: Jojo Dynamo

comments.text:

distances, using the warp-engines proposed by NASA to create wormholes. 
This is much faster than warp-drive alone, due to the penetration into 
subspace, as well as the fact that the engines would only need to generate 
a transient iimpulse. Likewise, black holes could be stationed with a huge 
stationary warp-engine which helped create an even longer wormhole for 
warp-driven ships, than they could do so on their own power.

comments.text:
Our sun isn't massive enough to create a black hole. you'd need a sun of at 
least 20 solar masses. Our sun will end up as a black dwarf. Before that 
it'll burn up it's fuel during the "Red Giant" phase. After which the outer 
layers will start drifting into outer space, then when it cools down turns 
into a hot white dwarf and eventually a hypothetical black dwarf (lost all 
of its heat) Starts in ~1.1 Billion years, Red Giant about ~5 Billion 
years. Total process ~12 Billion (white dwarf)

comments.text:
The "big crunch" was the hypothesis that gravity would eventually slow the 
expansion of the universe, causing it to eventually stop expanding, and 
then begin to collapse back onto itself as gravity pulled the matter in the 
universe back towards a gravitation center. This hypothesis, though a good 
one at the time, was made obsolete with the discovery that the expansion of 
our universe is actually speeding up, instead of slowing as the "big 
crunch" hypothesis predicted.

comments.text:
If you put some dots on a piece of rubber, and then stretch it, you'll 
notice that the further two dots are from each other, the faster they're 
moving apart. You'd also note that the dots are not actually moving across 
the rubber, it's the rubber itself that is expanding. It's the same way 
with the universe. Space itself is expanding, so nothing is actually 
traveling faster than light. It's the space between objects that is 
increasing faster than light.
comments.author: libalchris

comments.text:

What happens inside a black hole is inferred from Einstein's general theory 
of relativity. This theory has been tested. We've observed the curving of 
light around massive objects, and measured gravitational waves. We've also 
confirmed the constancy of the speed of light, which is central to the 
theory. This done, we can look at the implications of the theory. One of 
these implications is black holes. We observe black holes to exist, and 
infer the properties we can't measure from the theory.

Gravitationally it wouldn't be the same. Although the mass of the black 
hole would be the same as the star it came from, the radius would be many 
many times smaller. This would cause the gravitation to be exponentially 
bigger than the original star. The equation is g =Gm/r , where g is 
gravity, G is the gravitational constant, m is mass and r is the radius. As 
radius gets smaller, but mass stays constant, g gets bigger. Black holes 
aren't scary though.

change, except that we'd see one less star in the sky. Gravitationally, it 
would act exactly the same.

The definition of the event horizon is the surface where the gravity 
becomes so intense that light cannot escape. The light is not cancelled; it 
is bent to such a degree that it bends back toward the singularity. That;s 
why the hole is black; whatever is going on inside the event horizon will 
never have an effect on the space outside.

comments.text:
That is incorrect. A black hole has the properties of mass, angular 
momentum and electric charge. The Schwartzschild radius is dependent on the 
mass and spin. What the singularity MAY represent is a location of infinite 
density, not mass; that is conjecture, because we don't know what happens 
inside the event horizon, and infinite density is an impossible concept in 
classical physics.

comments.text:
Since we're talking a 3D object rather than 2D, it is better to say there 
is an insubstantial surface at the Schwartzschild radius called the event 
horizon that hides what goes on within it, and the singularity. We do 
not/can not know what goes on within the event horizon.
comments.author: puncheex2

comments.text:
Well, they fall into the event horizon at a speed approaching the speed of 
light, which is to say that matter acts no differently in the area around a 
black hole than it does anywhere else. What happens inside the event 
horizon we do not/can not know.
comments.author: puncheex2

comments.text:
That is true. If you had two identical solar systems, the only difference 
being the central star in one was collapsed into a BH of the same solar 
mass, the planets in the two solar systems would continue to orbit the 
center in exactly the same ways. The sun has a radius of 700,000 km, while 
a same-mass BH would have an event horizon of 3 km. A black hole becomes 
gravitationally voracious only when matter moves into the space that would 
be the body of the normal star, within 700,000 km of the BH.
comments.author: puncheex2

comments.text:
No. As far as we know now they continue growing until there is no more 
matter to fall in, then they VERY slowly evaporate.
comments.author: puncheex2

comments.text:
If there is no in-falling matter, the black hole becomes quiet, visible 
only because of the distortion of light and orbiting objects. In a galaxy 
that doesn't last long; gravitic interaction of stars and clouds of gas and 
dust keeps moving matter toward the center for the black hole to feed upon. 
The one at the center of our galaxy seems to be fairly quiet at the moment, 
but a gas cloud moving towards it that may light it up some in the near 
future (which was really 25,000 yrs ago, of course).
comments.author: puncheex2

comments.text:
Actually dark matter doesn't absorb light, it doesn't react with 
electromagnetic radiation at all. That is why it is transparent; matter has 
to interact with light in order to reflect, absorb or refract it in any 
way. The only interaction it has with our known universe seems to be 
gravitic.

comments.text:
To answer few questions asked here : size of a black hole is measured by 
the mass it represents, which is the accumulation of all matter it 
swallowed, plus the initial mass it had from the collapsed star that 
created it. Then, regarding dimensions, its size is measured by the 
diameter of its event horizon, or schwartzchild horizon, which is the 
invisbile line circling the singularity (the actual core, infinitly dense, 
small, and warm. This line is the no return line, from which nothing can 
escap

developed for observation. The theory of relativity only addresses the 
standard model of physics. Black Holes cannot be explained by using the 
standard model. Unification is attempting to explain what The Theory Of 
Relativity cannot. The Big Bang and Black Holes are addressed in "M Theory" 
mathematics. Black Holes occupy regions of space that are much older then 
where we currently reside.

current instruments.

comments.text:
*~ Cosmic Journeys : The Largest Black Holes In The Universe ~*

A supermassive black hole is the largest type of black hole in a galaxy, on 
the order of hundreds of thousands to billions of solar masses. Most--and 
possibly all--galaxies, including the Milky Wa y(see Sagittarius A), are 
believed to contain Supermassive black holes at their centers.

Donald Lynden-Bell and Martin Rees hypothetized in 1971 that the center of 
the Milky Way galaxy would contain a supermassive black hole. Sagittarius A 
was discovered and named on February 13 and 15, 1974, by astronomers Bruce 
Balick and Robert Brown using the baseline interferometer of the National 
Radio Astronomy Observatory. They discovered a radio source that emits 
synchrotronic radiation, also it was found to be dense and immobile because 
of its gravitation. Therefore, the first discovered supermassive black hole 
existed in the center of the Milky Way.

*Supermassive Black Holes Outside The Milky Way*

It is now widely accepted that the center of nearly every galaxy contains a 
supermassive black hole. 

It is believed that black holes and their host galaxies coevolved between 
300-800 million years after the Big Bang, passing through a quasar phase. 

The nearby Andromeda Galaxy, 2.5 million light-years away, contains a 
(1.1–2.3) × 108 (110-230 million) solar mass central black hole, 
significantly larger than the Milky Way's. 

The largest supermassive black hole in the Milky Way's neighborhood appears 
to be that of M87, weighing in at (6.4 ± 0.5) × 109 (~6.4 billion) solar 
masses at a distance of 53.5 million light years.

On 5 December 2011 astronomers discovered the largest super massive black 
hole yet found to be that of NGC 4889, weighing in at 21 billion solar 
masses at a distance of 336 million light-years away in the Coma 
constellation.

Some galaxies, such as Galaxy 0402+379, appear to have two supermassive 
black holes at their centers, forming a binary system. 

Binary supermassive black holes are believed to be a common consequence of 
galactic mergers. The binary pair in OJ 287, 3.5 billion light years away, 
contains the previous most massive black hole known (until the December 
2011 discovery, with a mass estimated at 18 billion solar masses.

A supermassive black hole was recently discovered in the dwarf galaxy 
Henize 2-10, which has no bulge. The precise implications for this 
discovery on black hole formation are unknown, but may indicate that black 
holes formed before bulges.

On March 28, 2011, a supermassive black hole (SMBH) was for the first time 
seen tearing a mid-size star apart. That is, according to astronomers, the 
only likely explanation of the observations that day of sudden X-ray 
radiation and the follow-up broad-band observations.

The source was previously an inactive galactic nucleus, and from study of 
the outburst the galactic nucleus is estimated to be a SMBH with mass of 
the order of a million solar masses. This rare event is assumed to be a 
relativistic outflow (material being emitted in a jet at a significant 
fraction of the speed of light) from a star tidally disrupted by the SMBH. 
A significant fraction of a solar mass of material is expected to have 
accreted onto the SMBH. Subsequent long-term observation will allow this 
assumption to be confirmed if the emission from the jet decays at the 
expected rate for mass accretion onto a SMBH.

Info via: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole﻿

comments.text:
1) Excerpt: Evolution is a theory. It is also a fact. And facts and 
theories are different things, not rungs in a hierarchy of increasing 
certainty. Facts are the world's data. Theories are structures of ideas 
that explain and interpret facts. Facts do not go away when scientists 
debate rival theories to explain them. (continued below)
comments.author: CynicalSkeptic1

comments.text:
Excerpt: James McCarter of Divergence Incorporated states that the work of 
2001 Nobel Prize winner Leland Hartwell which has substantial implications 
for combatting cancer relied heavily on the use of evolutionary knowledge 
and predictions. McCarter points out that 47 of the last 50 Nobel Prizes in 
medicine or physiology also depended on the use of EVOLUTIONARY theory. 
Scientists don't win Nobel Prizes in medicine and physiology based on an 
erroneous theory.
comments.author: CynicalSkeptic1

Accretion discs almost certainly produce magnetic fields of their own, 
you're right about that. But the black holes themselves can also have mag 
fields--in fact, they are classified based on three properties(the only 
properties a BH can have); mass, spin, and mag field. If you're interested, 
check burro.astr.cwru.edu/stu/advanced/stars_blackhole.html for a short but 
succinct description of BH theory.
comments.author: Tsurugi

comments.text:
Yes. The acceleration due to gravity within the event horizon of a black 
hole is high enough to raise escape velocity above the speed of light. But 
it's not really 'suction', so you can't really say it's 'faster'. Instead 
of thinking of it as suction, think of gravity as a slope. The stronger the 
gravity, the steeper the slope.

comments.text:
So Evolution works through 2 main processes: Natural Selection and 
Mutation. Natural selection is what I described in the end: The lifeform 
with the best traits suvives, and thus reproduces more, its genes then 
accumulate. Mutations can also cause the loss, or the gaining, of genes. We 
lost a gene that inhibits brain growth in chimps which still have it. 
Nylon-eating bacteria gained I think 275 new basepairs, which gave it the 
ability to produce nylonase, an enzyme that helps to digest nylon.
comments.author: Helge129

comments.text:
I'm not a biologist, but a game designer and artist...but here goes. When 
DNA replicates, every now and then there's an error, a cytosine being 
replaced by an adenine for example. That's called a mutation. Mutations can 
have no effect, beneficial effect, or have a negative effect on the 
life-form. These only have a major influence if they occur before the 
fertilized egg starts to divide. If a mutation gives a lifeform an edge 
over others of its species, it survives and reproduces more. (cont.)

comments.text:
The largest black holes in the universe. How did such large black holes 
form so early in the universe? Galaxies form in clusters, and merge into 
larger and larger galaxies. Galaxies have supermassive black holes at their 
centers, and according to Einstein's relativity, when they orbit each other 
the energy in the orbits can be transmitted into gravitational waves, 
allowing the black holes to meet and merge. Energetic jets from these black 
holes are the most powerful eruptions known about since the big bang, using 
the same amount of energy as several billion supernovae. The jets contain 
high levels of metallic elements. When 2 black holes merge, their combined 
jets create a huge final blast.﻿
comments.author: Sarangan Sara

are powered by; gravity. The only difference is that back then, there was 
lots of gas for them to feed on, so they tended to be more active than 
modern supermassive black holes and the average quasar accreted 10 solar 
masses of gas each year. Eventually the gas ran out, either having been 
accreted or blasted away by radiation pressure and relativistic jets, and 
things settled down.

comments.text:
Yes. This discovery came about when Stephen Hawking discovered that black 
holes should radiate energy due to quantum mechanical processes. This 
radiation is called Hawking radiation. As a black hole radiates energy, it 
shrinks and the more it shrinks, the more it radiates and so finally it 
will completely evaporate. However, the timescale for this is extremely 
long: a black hole of the mass of the Sun will take more than a billion 
times the age of the universe to evaporate completely.

The event horizon theoretically defines a sphere around a black hole beyond 
which the acceleration due to gravity raises escape velocity above 
lightspeed. Newtonian/Einstein physics suggests nothing can overcome that. 
Quantum physics does not. And in any case, black holes have magnetic 
fields...so there, at least, is one force that can advance out past the 
event horizon. I think you're right that the accretion discs are the 
primary source of shock-waves...but a merge may have quantum emanations.

comments.text:
Humans cannot even know the exact momentum and position of a single 
particle SIMULTANEOUSLY due to the inherent Heisenberg Uncertainty 
Principle. Yet, humans trust computer models of motions of large-scale 
structures such as galaxies supposedly on a scale of billions of years?! 
Pure baloney. If I decided to stand up, that would theoretically affect 
everything in the universe since my body has mass. But will NASA calculate 
THAT?! Of course not. And little changes can become big changes over time.

In science, pretty much everything is a theory. And that's not bad or not 
proven actually. What you have to be cautious about is hypotheses. Theories 
are hypotheses, supported by factual or experimental evidence. They are 
considered to be the best explanation available in science, so don't let 
the stupid media deceive you. Theory becomes a law, when it predicts 
something correctly. Black Hole theory is backed by tons of evidence, so 
don't worry, they really are there
